filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of nineteen separate prints designed and etched or engraved by Blake. The original works are housed in seven collections, including the Bodleian Library, British Museum, Robert N. Essick collection, Fitzwilliam Museum, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and National Gallery of Art, Washington. These separate prints join two others, Deaths Door and George Cumberland’s Card, and four series of prints, all previously published, to complete this important category of Blake's endeavors as a printmaker.
The new group of nineteen includes Blake’s first separate engraving, Joseph of Arimathea among the Rocks of Albion, executed while still an apprentice, and two of his masterpieces in mixed-method etching/engraving, the large Job and Ezekiel plates. The Accusers of Theft Adultery Murder, Lucifer and the Pope in Hell, and Albion rose depict Blake's response to the political revolutions of the late eighteenth century. Blake printed these three, plus A Dream of Thiralatha and Joseph of Arimathea Preaching to the Inhabitants of Britain, in colors as part of his development of relief and planographic color printing in the mid-1790s. Other plates, ranging from The Approach of Doom to the Enoch lithograph and The Chaining of Orc, testify to Blake's lifelong experimentation with innovative graphic techniques. He produced Deaths Door and the Virgil Relief Etching as book illustrations but they were never published as such and exist only as unique, separate impressions. Introductions to each work offer information on medium, changes in state, dating, and subject. Blake’s Laocoön etching/engraving, sometimes considered a separate plate, is included among the Illuminated Books in the Archive.
Late in his career, c. 1820-25 or even extending into his final year, Blake returned to several of his earlier separate engravings, dramatically revising the interplay of darkness and light in their designs and adding new inscriptions on some plates that alter their meaning. These final states of Joseph of Arimathea among the Rocks of Albion, Job, Ezekiel, The Accusers, Albion rose, and Blake's largest and most ambitious print, Chaucers Canterbury Pilgrims, are included, along with extant earlier states. The publication of these and other multiple states and printings offer insights into Blake's development as a printmaker and changes in his thematic interests over several decades.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

provenance.note: Possibly one of the works acquired from Blake in Aug. 1797 by James Curry; acquired when bound with *The Song of Los* Copy B (and perhaps other works by Blake—see Essick page 32) between 1856 and 1862 by Benjamin D'Israeli, later Earl of Beaconsfield; disbound and sold Hodgson auction, London, 14 Jan. 1904, lot 227 (£15.5s. to the dealer Bernard Quaritch, possibly acting for William A. White); sold from White's collection in May 1929 by the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach to Lessing J. Rosenwald with *Joseph of Arimathea Preaching* Copy 1B for $3000; given by Rosenbach to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C., in 1943.

objnote.p: This impression is probably in the second state of three. See Essick page 31 for the reasons for believing that this color printed impression is in the second state. The date of the conversion of the plate from its first state, dated 1793 in the imprint, into this second state was no later than 1796 when this color-printed impression was produced. No inscriptions are visible and there is no traced intaglio impression in the second state. However, an impression (now untraced) with printed inscriptions, owned by Edward D. Hooper, was exhibited at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts in 1891. The exhibition catalogue, pages 32-33, no. 11, records a title inscription ("When the senses are shaken / And the soul is driven to madness Page 56") and the same imprint as in the first state ("Publishd June 5: 1793 by W Blake Lambeth"). Fragments of these inscriptions appear in some impressions of the third (final) state. The title in this second state is quoted from "Prologue, Intended for a Dramatic Piece of King Edward the Fourth," page 56 in Blake's *Poetical Sketches* of 1783 (see Erdman page 439). The identification of the figures as "The Accusers of Theft Adultery Murder" and "The Accuser The Judge & The Executioner" in the third state inscriptions may not pertain to this second state. This impression is numbered "3" in pen and ink top right, not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three male figures stand in a line with bodies turned to face right. The rightmost figure is nude above the waist and wears blue breeches. He has short curly hair and turns his head to look to the left. His brow is furrowed and his mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of fear. Both arms are bent and crossed in front of his chest. With his right hand, he holds the haft of a sword, which is pointed upward. His legs are together with the right leg slightly in front of the left. To his left, the middle figure turns his head to look forward. He has long hair, a mustache, and a beard; he also wears a spiky crown. He may be a king. His eyes are wide and his mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of fear. His teeth and tongue are visible. He raises both bent arms upward and clutches his head with both hands. The fingers of both hands appear to be curled inward. This figure wears a cape or cloak that extends down behind his thighs and a suit of armor. His legs are together with the right leg slightly in front of the left. The leftmost figure stands with his body facing right and head turned to look left and down. He has short hair, a mustache, and a beard. He wears a shirt composed of small circles, which may indicate chain mail, and pleated breeches or skirt(?). His costume suggests that of a Roman soldier. His right arm appears to be at his side. He may hold the spear pointed upward above the middle figure's head with his left hand (which is not visible). Only the right leg and foot of the leftmost figure are visible. Indeterminate forms that may suggest vegetation(?) are visible around the group of three figures. In the background sky, a red cloud or smoke behind the figures' heads may descend from the top right corner of the composition. Another cloud or plume of smoke appears lower right behind the figures' legs.
